sen.j: 内藤 家長（ないとう いえなが、1546年（天文 (元号)15年）- 1600年9月8日（慶長5年8月1日 (旧暦)））は、戦国時代 (日本)から安土桃山時代にかけての武将。
sen.e: Ienaga NAITO (1546 - September 8, 1600) was a busho (Japanese military commander) over the Sengoku period to the Azuchi-momoyama period.
Ienaga NAITO (1546 - September 8, 1600) was a busho (Japanese military commander) from the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) to the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせました。
sen.e: Ienaga NAITO (1546 - September 8, 1600) was a busho (Japanese military commander) from the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) to the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
He was the retainer of the Tokugawa clan.
The retainer of the Tokugawa clan.
The retainer of the Tokugawa clan.
He was the son of Kiyonaga NAITO.
The son of Kiyonaga NAITO.
The son of Kiyonaga NAITO.
He was the cousin of Masanari NAITO.
The cousin of Masanari NAITO.
The cousin of Masanari NAITO.
His wife was the daughter of Tadanaga MATSUDAIRA.
His wife was the daughter of Tadanaga MATSUDAIRA.
His wife was the daughter of Tadanaga MATSUDAIRA.
He was the father of Masanaga NAITO.
The father of Masanaga NAITO.
The father of Masanaga NAITO.

sen.j: 義兄に内藤信成がいる。
sen.e: His Gikei (brother-in-law) was Nobunari NAITO.
His older brothers-in-law included Nobunari NAITO.
His older brothers-in-law included Nobunari NAITO.
Biography and Personal Profile
Biography and Personal Profile
Biography and Personal Profile

sen.j: 三河の内藤氏は家長の祖父の代から松平氏（徳川氏）に仕えた譜代の家臣の家柄であり、父・清長が晩年になって儲けた子の家長は徳川家康に仕え、義兄の信成から内藤家の家督を譲られて跡を継いだ。
sen.e: The Mikawa Naito clan was the house standing of the retainer of the daimyo in hereditary vassalage to the Matsudaira house (the Tokugawa house) since Ienaga's grandfather was the head of the family, and Ienaga, who was born as the son of Kiyonaga in his later years, served Ieyasu TOKUGAWA and took over as the head of the family from his Gikei, Nobunari.

As Naito clan in Mikawa was the vassal family offudai (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) served the Matsudaira clan (Tokugawa clan) since Ienaga's grandfather, Ienaga, who was the son of Kiyonaga in later life, served Ieyasu TOKUGAWA and succeeded to the head of the Naito family from the older brother-in-law Nobunari.

As Naito clan in Mikawa was the vassal family offudai (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) served the Matsudaira clan (Tokugawa clan) since Ienaga's grandfather, Ienaga, who was the son of Kiyonaga in later life, served Ieyasu TOKUGAWA and succeeded to the head of the Naito family from the older brother-in-law Nobunari.

sen.j: 父の清長と同様に武勇に優れており、また弓の名手で「無双の弓手」と称えられた。
sen.e: Like his father, Kiyonaga, he was excellent in heroism as well as in his skill with the bow and enjoyed the name of 'unrivaled archer.'
Like his father, Kiyonaga, he was excellent in heroism as well as in his skill with the bow and enjoyed the name of 'unrivaled archer.'
Like his father, Kiyonaga, he was excellent in heroism as well as in his skill with the bow and enjoyed the name of 'unrivaled archer.'

sen.j: また、父同様に一向一揆の門徒でもあったが三河一向一揆の時に家長は父と訣別して、一揆方に加わらず義理の伯父に当たる家康に従軍し、一揆衆を鎮圧するなどで忠節を貫き、家康から大いに信頼された。
sen.e: Also like his father, he was the follower of the Ikko Ikki (Ikko sect's revolt), but at the Mikawa Ikko Ikki, he took part in a campaign of Ieyasu, his uncle-in-law, instead of the Ikko sect followers, by parting from his father and he remained faithful to Ieyasu by suppressing the troops of the Ikko sect's revolt and earned Ieyasu's great trust.

Also like his father, he was the follower of the Ikko Ikki (Ikko sect's revolt), however, at the Mikawa Ikko Ikki (Ikko sect's revolt in Mikawa Province), Ienaga parted from his father to participate in the army of Ieyasu, his uncle-in-law, instead in the Ikko sect followers remained faithful to Ieyasu by suppressing the troops of the Ikko sect's revolt and earned his great trust.

Also like his father, he was the follower of the Ikko Ikki (Ikko sect's revolt), however, at the Mikawa Ikko Ikki (Ikko sect's revolt in Mikawa Province), Ienaga parted from his father to participate in the army of Ieyasu, his uncle-in-law, instead in the Ikko sect followers remained faithful to Ieyasu by suppressing the troops of the Ikko sect's revolt and earned his great trust.

sen.j: 以降も徳川家主要の合戦の多くに参加し、大いなる武功を挙げた。
sen.e: After that, he participated in many of Tokugawa clan's major battles and achieved great military exploits.
After that, he participated in many of Tokugawa clan's major battles and achieved great military exploits.
After that, he participated in many of Tokugawa clan's major battles and achieved great military exploits.

sen.j: その功績から家康が関東に移った時、上総国佐貫藩の地に2万石の所領を与えられた。
sen.e: As the reward for it, when Ieyasu moved to the Kanto region, Ienaga was granted a 20,000 koku fief in the Sanuki Domain, Kazusa Province.
As the reward for it, when Ieyasu moved to the Kanto region, Ienaga was granted a 20,000 koku fief in the Sanuki Domain, Kazusa Province.
As the reward for it, when Ieyasu moved to the Kanto region, Ienaga was granted a 20,000 koku fief in the Sanuki Domain, Kazusa Province.

sen.j: 慶長5年（1600年）、鳥居元忠や松平家忠らと共に伏見城を守備して石田三成ら西軍の挙兵を誘った。
sen.e: In 1600, he was assigned to Fushimi-jo Castle together with Mototada TORII and Ietada MATSUDAIRA and induced the rising of the Western army led by Mitsunari ISHIDA.
In 1600, he kept Fushimi-jo Castle together with Mototada TORII and Ietada MATSUDAIRA and induced the rising of the Western squad led by Mitsunari ISHIDA.
In 1600, he kept Fushimi-jo Castle together with Mototada TORII and Ietada MATSUDAIRA and induced the rising of the Western squad led by Mitsunari ISHIDA.

sen.j: 目論見どおり、三成ら西軍は挙兵したが、家長は元忠、家忠らと共に関ヶ原の戦いの前哨戦である伏見城の戦いで戦死した。
sen.e: According to their plan scheme, the Western army led by Mitsunari rose, but Ienaga was killed in the Battle of Fushimi-jo Castle, the preliminary skirmish of the Battle of Sekigahara, together with Mototada and Ietada.

According to their plan scheme, the Western squad including Mitsunari rose, but Ienaga was killed in the Battle of Fushimi-jo Castle, the preliminary skirmish of the Battle of Sekigahara, together with Mototada and Ietada.

According to their plan scheme, the Western squad including Mitsunari rose, but Ienaga was killed in the Battle of Fushimi-jo Castle, the preliminary skirmish of the Battle of Sekigahara, together with Mototada and Ietada.
He died at age 55.
Died at the age of 55.
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせました。
sen.e: Died at the age of 55.

sen.j: 彼の死後、家督は長男の政長が後を継ぎ、戦死した父の功績を賞されて、1万石を加増されている。
sen.e: After his death, his eldest son, Masanaga took over as the head of the family and to honor his killed father's achievements, his revenues were increased by 10,000 koku.
After his death, his oldest son, Masanaga took over as the head of the family and to honor his father's achievements killed in the battle, his revenues were increased by 10,000 koku.
After his death, his oldest son, Masanaga took over as the head of the family and to honor his father's achievements killed in the battle, his revenues were increased by 10,000 koku.
